page.title: 03CORNISH HEDGEROWS
page.content: A typical Cornish hedge is built mostly of local stone, wider at the base than at the top with an infill of earth through the middle.The top course of stones, called{copestones}or {Jack and Jill}are often placed vertically at an angle to permit drainage. On top of the hedge, turf from the immediate area is placed. {Colonisation}of bushes in a Cornish hedge is slow because of its structure and the exposed nature of the countryside.However, grasses and wild flowers thrive in the shelter provided and are able to grow in and on the hedge because of the soil used in its construction. The lack of shrubs,bushes and trees in the hedge does limit this environment compared to some 'up-country' hedgerows which are made entirely of plants.
